Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: GEM: Global Simulations of Non-Ideal Transport in the Magnetotail
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plasma from the tail reconnection site is transported into the inner magnetosphere where it forms the ring current. The most common type of model for studying this transport is a global magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) model. These are frequently coupled with models of the plasma transport in the inner magnetosphere since MHD models do not describe the physics well in the inner magnetosphere. This is a project to enhance the physics of the MHD models in the tail where they work best. This effort will add diamagnetic (pressure driven) drifts, inertial drifts, finite Larmor radius effects on the pressure tensor, and the energy dependence of these drifts. The improved model will be used to study magnetospheric convection, fast bursty bulk flows and dipolarization fronts, the Kelvin-Helmholtz instability and the structure of thin current sheets.
The improved simulation code when coupled with an inner magnetosphere model will be useful in studying transport during magnetic storms. Therefore it will valuable for space weather studies. Since space weather represents a series hazard this work may be of significant societal value.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For many years the global simulation of the magnetosphere has relied on single-fluid MHD (magnetohydrodynamic) computer codes that model the Earth's space environment with a single ion component, hydrogen, that interacts with the magnetic field of the solar wind and the Earth. However, this picture is limited in a couple of ways: There are more than one type of ion, indeed, there are differing populations of just hydrogen. Second, the usual MHD equations assume that all ions move at the same speed perpendicular to the magnetic field. This can be viewed as the plasma moving with the magnetic field, the frozen-in flux condition. At small scales, this is no longer true. In fact most of the magnetosphere is a place where the relative motions of the individual ion species relative to the average bulk motion is appreciable. In the inner magnetosphere these motions dominate.   
This project sought to address both of these problems.  We used a multi-fluid version of the well-known global MHD code, the Lyon-Fedder-Mobarry code (LFM), to study the interaction of multiple species within the magnetosphere. While there are a number of groups using their own multi-fluid MHD codes, we made substantial contributions to understanding the role of the plasmasphere (the dense, cold hydrogen region near the Earth) and of oxygen outflowing from the polar ionosphere.
A more speculative part of the project was the inclusion of the drifts of individual species within the MHD framework. Formally, this means including the action of the Lorentz force individually on each plasma component instead of using a bulk average. In addition to treating the ion motions differently, the Hall electric field must also be included. The Hall field is an important component of the physics of magnetic reconnection that powers the solar wind-magnetosphere coupling and that produces the internal convection within the magnetotail. The importance of these drifts can be seen in the figure which shows the effects of these drifts on a hot oxygen component in the magnetosphere. The left hand panel shows the flow vectors for this specie in the standard MHD model; the right shows the effects of these drifts. The net effect of the drifts is to cause this specie to  preferentially drift toward the dusk (upper) side of the magnetosphere.
Thes important effects are being include in ongoing work. The original project goals included developing a global model with energy dependent channels that model an actual velocity distribution. This was not successful because of difficulties in accounting for the effects like MHD shocks, but the code developed can still be applied to important magnetospheric questions, such as reconnection of a mixed hydrogen-oxygen fluid in the magnetotail.
